In the view of discrimination of the past, there are four theories of universal permanence.
One, by being able to remember one eon of destruction and formation,

they then grasp that the self and the world are both permanent.
Question: Why do they make this grasping?
Answer: They reckon it is due to transformation or concealment and manifestation.
The theorists of transformation
make this grasping: milk transforms into yogurt,
seeds transform into sprouts,
fuel transforms into ashes.
Such categories.
If something continues from that, it is all transformed by that.
Because when that dharma ceases, this dharma arises,
therefore the self-nature of all dharmas abides permanently.
The theorists of concealment and manifestation
make this grasping:
The self-nature of dharmas is either concealed or manifested.
They see that in this place, the great earth, continents, Mount Sumeru, other mountains, great oceans, trees, and so forth, which previously had such shapes and appearances, have been destroyed.
Later, in this place, the great earth and so forth are again formed with such shapes and appearances.
They then think:
That which is invisible between those [destructions] is not destroyed.
However, during the destruction eon, that nature becomes hidden, and during the formation eon, that nature appears again.
Moreover, the seven bodies of the sage are always motionless, do not touch each other, and cannot be harmed. Therefore, they think:
I and what I remember both exist eternally.
Because of this, they see that both I and the world are eternal.
Second, due to being able to remember the events of one, two, or three lifetimes, up to a hundred thousand lifetimes,
they then grasp that both I and the world are eternal.
Because of the transformation or concealment of [the self],
if they are able to remember the destruction and formation of the external world,ğŸ”½because they see that in this place, the great earth, continents,
and so forth, which previously had such shapes and appearances,
up to life cannot be harmed.
If one cannot remember the destruction and formation of the external vessel, the principle of the permanence of the world does not need to be explained.
Therefore, one thinks like this.
I and what I remember are both permanent.
Because of this, one sees that I and the world are both permanent and abiding.
Question: What is the difference between this and the first theory?
Answer: Although the former remembers much, he has not yet attained mastery over the uninterrupted arising of all memories.
Now, although he remembers little, he has already attained mastery over the uninterrupted arising of all memories.
Third, by means of the heavenly eye, one sees the continuity of the aggregates of sentient beings at the time of death and birth.

That is to say, one sees that immediately after the aggregates of the death existence, the intermediate existence appears.ğŸ”½One also sees that immediately after the aggregates of the intermediate existence, the aggregates of the birth existence appear.
And one sees that immediately after the aggregates of the birth existence, the aggregates of the prior existence appear.
The aggregates of the prior existence continue in a state of continuity up to the death existence.
It is like the continuity of a flowing water or a burning lamp.
Because of not being aware of subtle arising and ceasing, one gives rise to the notion of permanence regarding the aggregates.
Therefore one grasps that the self and the world are both permanent.
Because of the transformation or concealment and manifestation,

Therefore one thinks,
The self and what is seen are both permanent.
Because of this, one sees that the self and the world are both permanent.
Fourth, due to investigation and analysis not knowing as it truly is,

They think,
There are dharmas that are always existent,
and there are dharmas that are eternally non-existent. Non-existence cannot give rise to existence, and existence cannot cease.
They grasp that cause and effect from beginningless time are only of one nature, without ceasing and without arising.
Therefore it is included in the views of the past limit.
If they grasp form as the self,

If they grasp mind and so forth as the self,
Because the mind and other dharmas arise in succession, arise in similarity, and arise at all times.
Because they are unable to understand subtle arising and cessation.
Because they are able to remember past experiences.
Because the activities before and after are mutually similar and do not obstruct each other.
They then grasp them as being permanent.
Due to such false investigation and discernment,
they grasp the self and the world as both being permanent.ğŸ”½These four kinds of views of the past that grasp permanence are due to eons, birth and death, arising, investigation, and discernment.
They arise due to four things.
As for the four kinds of views of partial permanence,
one is that after death in the Brahma world, one is reborn here.
Due to attaining the supernormal power of recollecting past lives, one makes such a grasping.
We are all created by the Great Brahma King.
The Brahma King who creates us abides there permanently.
We who are created are therefore impermanent.
Second, having heard that the Brahma King has such a view and establishes such a doctrine,ğŸ”½The primary elements are impermanent.
The mind is permanent.
Or, reversing this, they say that the mind is impermanent and the great elements are permanent, and they are the same as those ascetics. They either dwell in the Brahma world or are born here.
Or, hearing this kind of principle from each other, they make this attachment.
We take the Great Brahma Heaven King as the standard.
Therefore, one part of the world is permanent and one part is impermanent.
The third kind of person first dies from the Heaven of Playful Forgetfulness and is reborn here.
Because they attain the supernormal power of recollecting past abodes, they make this attachment.
The beings in that heaven who do not play excessively and forget mindfulness abide there permanently.
We, because of excessive play and forgetfulness, died from that place and therefore are impermanent.
The fourth kind of person first dies from the Heaven of Angry Intention and is reborn here.
Because they attain the supernormal power of recollecting past abodes, they make this attachment.
The beings in that heaven who do not become extremely angry and glare at each other abide there permanently.
We, because of extreme mutual anger and glaring at each other, died from that place and therefore are impermanent.
Question: In what places do these gods reside?
Some say:
They reside on the terraces of Mount Sumeru.
Some say:
They are the thirty-three heavens.
Thus, these four kinds of views of partial eternalism regarding the past

As for the two theories of causeless origination,
one is from those who die as non-percipient sentient beings and are reborn here.
Because they attain the supernormal power of recollecting past lives, they can remember the mind emerging from the non-percipient state and the subsequent states,
but they cannot remember the states prior to the emerging mind.
They then think:
I was originally non-existent at that time and arose.
All dharmas are also like me, and should originally be non-existent and arise.
Because of this, they grasp that both the self and the world arise without a cause, spontaneously.
The second is due to the false investigation through discursive thought.

Moreover, one thinks like this:
One presently sees that the colors and shapes of peacocks, pheasants, chickens, and so forth, as well as mountains, rocks, grasses, trees, flowers, fruits, thorns, and so forth,
